issues.description: The problem statement refers to a method named 'linkParent(Person person, Person parent)' while the template and solution define and expect a method named 'addParent(Person person, Person parent)' in PersonService. This name mismatch between the specification and the provided code can confuse students about which method to implement and test against.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the problem statement use the same method name and signature as the template/solution. Replace references to 'linkParent(Person person, Person parent)' with 'addParent(Person person, Person parent)' (and ensure any example/test names in the text match the addParent naming). This preserves the intended behavior while removing the naming inconsistency that could mislead students.

issues.description: The problem statement refers to a method named 'linkParent(Person person, Person parent)' when describing the required behavior for adding a parent (line(s) 99–106). However, both the template and the solution use the method name addParent(...) in PersonService. This inconsistent identifier for the same conceptual operation (adding a parent to a person) can confuse students when mapping the textual requirements to the provided template and the expected implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the name across artifacts. Update the problem statement to refer to addParent(Person person, Person parent) (or note explicitly that linkParent is the same as addParent) so the textual requirements match the template and solution. Alternatively, add a linkParent(...) delegating to addParent(...) in the template/service API, but changing the problem text is the simpler, less error-prone fix.
